{
  "concepts": [
    {"term": "aliasing problem", "category": "signal_processing"},
    {"term": "sampling", "category": "signal_processing"},
    {"term": "sampling rate", "category": "signal_processing"},
    {"term": "high-frequency signal", "category": "signal_processing"},
    {"term": "reconstruct the signal", "category": "reconstruction"},
    {"term": "higher-frequency components", "category": "signal_processing"},
    {"term": "right sampling rate", "category": "signal_processing"}
  ],
  "evidence": [
    "It happens when the sampling rate is too low to capture the higher-frequency components.",
    "choosing the right sampling rate is so critical in signal processing.",
    "If we don’t sample it frequently enough — meaning, we don’t take enough points per second — we miss those small peaks and dips.",
    "the reconstructed version can look like a completely different signal, with a false shape or even the wrong frequency."
  ]
}

evidence: It happens when the sampling rate is too low to capture the higher-frequency components.
choosing the right sampling rate is so critical in signal processing.
If we don’t sample it frequently enough - meaning, we don’t take enough points per second - we miss those small peaks and dips.
the reconstructed version can look like a completely different signal, with a false shape or even the wrong frequency.
